__data__.text: Radio Corporation of America (RCA) acquired New York City radio station WEAF from American Telephone & Telegraph (AT&T).
Westinghouse, a shareholder in RCA, owned a competing outlet in Newark pioneer station WJZ.
In 1923, RCA transferred WJZ from Westinghouse to RCA, and moved it to New York City.
WEAF acted as a laboratory for AT&T's manufacturing and supply outlet Western Electric.
The Bell System, AT&T's telephone utility, developed technologies to transmit voice- and music-grade audio over short and long distances.
WEAF maintained a regular schedule of radio programs, including some of the first commercially sponsored programs.
In 1922, WEAF linked with Outlet Company-owned WJAR in Providence, Rhode Island, and with AT&T's station in Washington, D.C., WCAP.
RCA saw an advantage in sharing programming and attempted to transmit audio between cities via low-quality telegraph lines.
AT&T refused outside companies access to its high-quality phone lines.
In 1925, AT&T decided that WEAF and its embryonic network were incompatible with the company's primary goal of providing a telephone service.
AT&T offered to sell WEAF to RCA in a deal that included the right to lease AT&T's phone lines for network transmission.
RCA spent $1 million to purchase WEAF and Washington sister station WCAP.
RCA merged WEAF and WCAP's facilities with surviving station WRC.
In late 1926, RCA announced the creation of a new division known as the National Broadcasting Company (NBC).
NBC's ownership was split among RCA (a majority partner at 50%), General Electric (which owned 30%), and Westinghouse (which owned the remaining 20%).
NBC officially started broadcasting on November 15, 1926.
WEAF and WJZ were operated side by side for about a year as part of the new NBC.
On
NBC outgrew its facilities at Fifth Avenue in 1933.
In the 1930s, NBC developed a network for shortwave radio stations, known as the NBC White Network.
General Electric was charged with antitrust violations in 1930.
General Electric was an early shareholder in RCA, which was NBC's founding parent company.
In 1930, General Electric decided to divest itself of RCA.
The newly separate company, RCA, signed leases to move its corporate headquarters into the new Rockefeller Center in 1931.
John D. Rockefeller Jr., the founder and financier of Rockefeller Center, arranged the deal with GE chairman Owen D. Young and RCA president David Sarnoff.

RCA became the lead tenant at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, known as the "RCA Building" (later the GE Building, now the Comcast Building), which housed NBC's production studios as well as theaters for RCA-owned RKO Pictures.
The iconic three-note NBC chimes came about after several years of development.
The three-note sequence, G-E'-C', was first heard over Red Network affiliate WSB in Atlanta.
An executive at NBC's New York headquarters heard the WSB version of the notes during the networked broadcast of a Georgia Tech football game and asked permission to use it on the national network.
NBC started to use the chimes sequence in 1931.
The three-note sequence became the first audio trademark to be accepted by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.
A variant sequence with an additional note, G-E'-C'-G, known as "the fourth chime", was used during significant events of extreme urgency.
The NBC chimes were mechanized in 1932 by Rangertone founder Richard H. Ranger.
The purpose of the NBC chimes was to send a low-level signal of constant amplitude that would be heard by the various switching stations staffed by NBC and AT&T engineers.
The Blue Network was formally named NBC Blue Network, Inc. for corporate purposes.
NBC Red was formally named NBC Red Network, Inc. for corporate purposes.
On January 8, 1942, the Blue Network and NBC Red divorced their operations.
The Blue Network was referred to on-air as either "Blue" or "Blue Network".
Blue Network Company, Inc. served as the official corporate name for the Blue Network.
NBC was known on-air as simply "NBC".
Investment firm Dillon, Read & Co. placed a $7.5 million bid for NBC Blue.
The bid from Dillon, Read & Co. for NBC Blue was rejected by NBC executive Mark Woods and RCA president David Sarnoff.
RCA sold Blue Network Company, Inc. to the American Broadcasting System for $8 million.
The American Broadcasting System was owned by Life Savers magnate Edward J. Noble.
The sale of Blue Network Company, Inc. to the American Broadcasting System was completed on October 12, 1943.
After the sale, Noble acquired the rights to the Blue Network name.
Noble also acquired leases on landlines, the New York studios, two-and-a-half radio stations, contracts with actors, and agreements with around 60 affiliates.
Noble sold off his existing New York City radio station WMCA to comply with FCC radio station ownership limits.
In 1944, Noble acquired the branding rights to the "American Broadcasting Company" name from George B. Storer.
The Blue Network became ABC officially on June 15, 1945.
NBC became home to many popular performers and programs on the air.
Bing Crosby, Al Jolson, Jack Benny, Edgar Bergen, Bob Hope, Fred Allen, and Burns and Allen called NBC home.
Arturo Toscanini's NBC Symphony Orchestra was featured on NBC.
NBC helped Toscanini create his NBC Symphony Orchestra.
Other programs featured on NBC included Vic and S
The Big Show was a radio program that featured Tallulah Bankhead as the hostess.

The Big Show attracted prestigious entertainers, including Fred Allen, Groucho Marx, Lauritz Melchior, Ethel Barrymore, Louis Armstrong, Ethel Merman, Bob Hope, Danny Thomas, Douglas Fairbanks Jr., and Ella Fitzgerald.
The Big Show received critical praise, but it did not last despite the positive reception.
The Big Show lasted for two years, and NBC lost around $1 million on the project.
NBC was only able to sell advertising time during the middle half-hour of The Big Show each week.
Monitor was NBC's last major radio programming push, and it began on June 12, 1955.
Sylvester "Pat" Weaver was the president of NBC when Monitor was created.
Monitor was a continuous all-weekend mixture of music, news, interviews, and features.
Well-known television personalities Dave Garroway, Hugh Downs, Ed McMahon, Joe Garagiola, and Gene Rayburn hosted Monitor.
Monitor tried to keep vintage radio alive by featuring segments from Jim and Marian Jordan (in character as Fibber McGee and Molly).
Peg Lynch's dialog comedy Ethel and Albert (with Alan Bunce) was also featured on Monitor.
Iconoclastic satirist Henry Morgan was also featured on Monitor.
Monitor was a success for a number of years, but after the mid-1960s, local stations were reluctant to break from their established formats to run non-conforming network programming.
Toscanini: The Man Behind the Legend was a weekly series commemorating the great conductor's NBC broadcasts and recordings.
Toscanini: The Man Behind the Legend ran for several years beginning in 1963.
After Monitor ended its 20-year run on January 26, 1975, little remained of NBC network radio beyond hourly newscasts and news features, and Sunday morning religious program The Eternal Light.
NBC launched the NBC News and Information Service (NIS) on
In the years 1988 and 1989, multiple transactions occurred in which radio stations were sold off. These transactions included Emmis Communications, Westinghouse, and Susquehanna Radio Corporation.
By January 1989, Westwood One announced that NBC Radio News would move to Mutual's Arlington, Virginia, facility.
Engineering operations and the affiliate relations department also followed NBC Radio News to Mutual's Arlington, Virginia, facility.
Further consolidation occurred in 1992, resulting in Mutual and NBC newscasts being jointly produced during overnights and weekends.
Both networks aired generic sportscasts through the weekend during this time.
In 1994, Westwood One purchased Unistar Radio Networks from Infinity Broadcasting.
Infinity then purchased 25 percent of Westwood One, becoming its largest shareholder and assuming control.
Infinity was acquired by Westinghouse Electric Corporation in June 1996 for $5 billion, which is equivalent to $9.33 billion in 2022.
CBS Radio Network also fell under Westwood One management after the acquisition.
The Mutual/NBC newsroom in Arlington closed on August 31, 1998.
CBS Radio News originated "Mutual" and "NBC" newscasts from New York after the newsroom closed.
"NBC"-branded newscasts produced by CBS were restricted to morning drive (ET) on weekdays beginning on April 17, 1999.
Westwood One retired the Mutual name outright at this time.
Remaining NBC affiliates were offered CNN Radio newscasts at all other times.
Westwood One partnered with NBC News to launch NBC News Radio on March 31, 2003.
NBC and MSNBC talent anchored NBC News Radio.
NBC News Radio was limited to one-minute newscasts on weekdays.
An audio simulcast of Meet the Press was also distributed by Westwood One starting in 2004 and continues to this day.
DuMont Laboratories and others offered the first home sets in 1938.
NBC took its cameras to professional football and baseball games in the New York City area in 1939.
The first NBC Television "network" program was broadcast on January 12, 1940.
A play titled "Meet The Wife" was originated at the W2XBS studios at Rockefeller Center and rebroadcast by W2XB/W2XAF in Schenectady.
W2XB/W2XAF received the New York station directly off-air from a tower atop a mountain.
The live signal was relayed to the Capital District by W2XB/W2XAF.
Occasional special events were broadcast in Philadelphia and Schenectady.
The most ambitious NBC television "network" program of the pre-war era was the telecast of the Republican National Convention held in Philadelphia in the summer of 1940.
The convention was fed live to the New York City and Schenectady stations.
Television sales in New York from 1939 to 1942 were disappointing.
The high cost of the sets and the lack of compelling regularly scheduled programming contributed to the poor sales.
Only a few thousand television sets were sold in the New York area.
Most of the sets were sold to bars, hotels and other public places.
The general public viewed special sports and news events at these places.
One special event was Franklin D. Roosevelt's second and final appearance on live television.
His speech at Madison Square Garden on October 28, 1940, was telecast over W2XBS.
The telecast reached receivers in the New York City area.
The FCC allowed full-fledged commercial television broadcasts to begin on July 1, 1941.
NBC station W2XBS in New York City received the first commercial license.
The call letters WNBT were adopted by W2XBS.
The first official, paid television advertisement broadcast by any U.
The Voice of Firestone, a radio show on NBC since 1928, had a television offshoot called The Voice of Firestone Televues.
The Voice of Firestone Televues was the first regularly scheduled program of the NBC television network.
The War As It Happens was a local news program that was fed to Schenectady and Philadelphia on the NBC Television Network in April 1944.
On V-E Day, May 8, 1945, WNBT broadcast several hours of news coverage and remotes from around New York City.
The 1947 World Series featured two New York City area teams, the Yankees and the Dodgers.
Television sales boomed locally during the 1947 World Series.
Additional stations along the East Coast and in the Midwest were connected by coaxial cable through the late 1940s.
The first transcontinental telecasts took place in September 1951.
Milton Berle was the first major star of television.
Milton Berle's Texaco Star Theatre began in June 1948.
Under Sylvester "Pat" Weaver, NBC launched Today and The Tonight Show.
Weaver also launched the genre of periodic 90-minute network "spectaculars", network-produced motion pictures and the live 90-minute Sunday afternoon series Wide Wide World.
Weaver left the network in 1955 in a dispute with its chairman David Sarnoff.
David Sarnoff subsequently named his son Robert Sarnoff as president.
In 1951, NBC commissioned Italian-American composer Gian Carlo Menotti to compose the first opera ever written for television.
The opera was called Amahl and the Night Visitors.
Amahl and the Night Visitors was a 45-minute work for which Menotti wrote both music and libretto.
The opera was about a disabled shepherd boy who meets the Three Wise Men and is miraculously cured when he offers his crutch to the newborn Christ Child.
CBS abandoned its color broadcast system after a series of limited, incompatible color broadcasts.
The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) approved RCA's color system in December 1953.
NBC was ready with color programming within days of the FCC's decision.
NBC began the transition with a few shows in 1954.
The Marriage is a TV show that aired all episodes in color on NBC, beginning in the summer of 1954.
In 1955, NBC broadcast a live production in color of Peter Pan, a new Broadway musical adaptation of J. M. Barrie's beloved play.
The 1955 Peter Pan broadcast starred Mary Martin as Peter and Cyril Ritchard in a dual role as Mr. Darling and Captain Hook.
The 1955 Peter Pan broadcast drew the highest ratings for a television program for that period.
NBC restaged Peter Pan as a live broadcast a mere ten months later.
In 1960, NBC restaged Peter Pan again, this time as a standalone special.
The 1960 Peter Pan special was videotaped so that it would no longer have to be performed live on television.
In 1956, NBC started a subsidiary, California National Productions (CNP), for merchandising, syndication and NBC opera company operations.
The first production of CNP was Silent Services.
By 1957, NBC planned to remove the opera company from CNP.
CNP was in discussion with MGM Television about handling syndication distribution for MGM series.
In 1956, WNBQ, NBC's owned-and-operated station in Chicago, became the first television station in the country to broadcast its programming in color.
WNBQ aired at least six hours of color broadcasts each day.
In 1959, NBC premiered a televised version of the radio program The Bell Telephone Hour.
The Bell Telephone Hour aired in color from its debut.
The program aired on the NBC television
NBC did not broadcast another made-for-TV film for two years after performing well in the ratings with presentations.
In 1967, NBC made a deal with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) to acquire the broadcast rights to the classic 1939 film The Wizard of Oz.
CBS, which had been televising The Wizard of Oz annually since 1956, did not meet MGM's increased fee to renew its television rights.
The Wizard of Oz had been one of the few programs that CBS had telecast in color.
By 1967, color broadcasts had become standard on television.
The Wizard of Oz became another title in the list of specials that NBC telecast in color after it acquired the broadcast rights.
NBC televised The Wizard of Oz without a hosted introduction, unlike CBS.
The Wizard of Oz was slightly edited for time when it was televised by NBC to make room for more commercials.
Despite the cuts, The Wizard of Oz continued to score excellent television ratings in the pre-VCR days.
Audiences were generally unable to see the film any other way at that time.
NBC aired The Wizard of Oz each year from 1968 to 1976.
CBS agreed to pay MGM more money to re-acquire the rights to show The Wizard of Oz in 1976.
The late 1960s brought big changes in the programming practices of the major television networks.
Baby boomers were reaching adulthood during the late 1960s.
The networks wanted to attract the large youth population that was highly attractive to advertisers.
The networks moved to clean house of a number of veteran shows.
NBC, CBS, and ABC began to realize that much of their existing programming had not only been running for years but had audiences that skewed older.
The networks defined adults between the ages of 18 and 49 as their main target audience.
The networks also targeted other age demographics: 35–45, 18–25 or
Fred Silverman became the president of NBC in 1978.
Silverman had previously worked at CBS and ABC.
Under Silverman's leadership, CHiPs, Barbara Mandrell and the Mandrell Sisters, Diff'rent Strokes, and Shōgun were successful shows on NBC.
Silverman struggled to produce hit shows for NBC.
Hello, Larry, Supertrain, Pink Lady and Jeff, The Krofft Superstar Hour, season six of Saturday Night Live, and The Waverly Wonders were unsuccessful shows during Silverman's tenure.
These shows struggled in the ratings and were often beaten by shows that Silverman had greenlit during his previous tenures at CBS and ABC.
Several longtime NBC affiliates defected to other networks during Silverman's presidency.

WSB-TV in Atlanta, WERO-TV in Bakersfield, WBAL-TV in Baltimore, WBRZ-TV in Baton Rouge, KTVQ in Billings, KRGV-TV in Brownsville, WSOC-TV in Charlotte, KOMU-TV in Columbia, Missouri, WDTN in Dayton, WAAY-TV in Decatur, KLAA in El Dorado, KVAL-TV in Eugene, WDAY-TV in Fargo, KFSM-TV in Fort Smith, WFRV-TV in Green Bay, WRTV in Indianapolis, WTLV in Jacksonville, WATE-TV in Knoxville, WJMN-TV in Marquette, KSTP-TV in Minneapolis-St. Paul, KTVL in Medford, KMID in Odessa, WMBB in Panama City, KOTA-TV in Rapid City, KGTV in San Diego, WSAV-TV in Savannah, WRGB in Schenectady, KSFY-TV in Sioux Falls, KCEN-TV in Temple, KLTV in Tyler, WATR-TV in Waterbury, and WTRF-TV in Wheeling defected from NBC.
Most of the defected stations were VHF stations, with some exceptions including WAAY-TV, WATR-TV, KLAA-TV, and KERO-TV
Wheeling, NBC ultimately upgraded its affiliation when it partnered with WTOV-TV in nearby Steubenville, Ohio.
WTRF-TV was the former affiliate in Wheeling.
After the partnership with WTOV-TV, NBC overtook WTRF-TV in the ratings by a large margin.
Other smaller television markets like Yuma, Arizona waited many years to get another local NBC affiliate.
KIVA was the first NBC affiliate in Yuma, and KYMA was the second.
The stations in Baltimore, Columbia, Dayton, Jacksonville, Savannah, and Temple have since rejoined the network.
El Dorado went to a full-time Fox affiliate after a long association with ABC.
Green Bay switched to CBS several years after being associated with ABC.
Bakersfield, where it went to ABC several years after it was a CBS affiliate.
In Rapid City, the KOTA calls now resist on a station owned by Gray Television.
After President Jimmy Carter pulled the U.S. team out of the 1980 Summer Olympics, NBC canceled a planned 150 hours of coverage.
The cancellation of the 1980 Summer Olympics coverage cost NBC $87 million in broadcast rights.
NBC had been counting on the broadcasts to help promote its new fall shows.
NBC had been estimated to pull in $170 million in advertising revenue from the 1980 Summer Olympics coverage.
The press was merciless towards Silverman.
The two most savage attacks on Silverman's leadership came from within the network.
A company that composed the promotional theme for NBC's "Proud as a Peacock" image campaign created a parody song called "Loud as a Peacock".
The "Loud as a Peacock" parody song was broadcast on Don Imus' program on WNBC radio in New York.
The "Loud as a Peacock" lyrics blamed Silverman for the network's problems.
The "Loud as a Peacock" lyrics included the line "The Peacock's
NBC canceled The Tomorrow Show in February 1982.
David Letterman started hosting Late Night with David Letterman on NBC in the 12:35 a.m. time slot.
Late Night with David Letterman premiered in February 1982.
Late Night with David Letterman lasted for 11 years.
Late Night with David Letterman served as the launching pad for another late-night talk franchise.
The Cosby Show premiered in 1984.
The Cosby Show led to a renewed interest in sitcoms.
Family Ties and Cheers saw their viewership increase from having Cosby as a lead-in.
NBC rose from third place to second in the ratings during the 1984-85 season.
NBC reached first place in the ratings during the 1985-86 season.
The Golden Girls, Miami Vice, 227, Night Court, Highway to Heaven, and Hunter were hits for NBC in the mid-1980s.
ALF, Amen, Matlock, L.A. Law, The Hogan Family, A Different World, Empty Nest, Unsolved Mysteries, and In the Heat of the Night were hits for NBC in the late 1980s.
Bob Wright was appointed as chairman of NBC in 1986.
NBC became the first American television network to broadcast programs in stereo in 1985.
NBC repaired its old affiliations with Savannah, Temple, Columbia, Jacksonville, and WOWT in the 1980s.
NBC conceived a syndication package for its owned-and-operated stations in the fall of 1987.
The syndication package was called "Prime Time Begins at 7:30".
The syndication package consisted of five sitcoms that each aired once a week.
The sitcoms were produced by various production companies contracted by NBC.
The five sitcoms were Marblehead Manor, She's the Sheriff, You Can't
The FCC loosened the Prime Time Access Rule in 1971, which had required networks to turn over the 7:30 p.m. (Eastern) time slot to local stations to program local or syndicated content.
The Financial Interest and Syndication Rules were also relaxed, which had prevented networks from producing content from their own syndication units to fill the void.
In 1987, NBC planned to increase output of in-house productions for the next year, including a series of half-hour dramedies.
NBC aired an experimental sitcom lineup for Thanksgiving weekend in 1987, consisting of Night Court, Beverly Hills Buntz, Family Ties, and My Two Dads.
Low ratings for NBC's daytime lineup were caused by the creation of a new soap opera set for spring 1988, Generations.
NBC integrated its NBC Enterprises division with NBC-TV and Corporate Communications in 1989.
NBC aired the first of eight consecutive Summer Olympic Games broadcasts when it covered the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea.
The 1988-89 season saw NBC have an astounding 17 series in Nielsen's year-end Top 30 most-watched network programs.
NBC ranked at first place in the weekly ratings for more than 12 months in the 1988-89 season.
1989 was NBC's final year of covering Major League Baseball, having done so in some shape or form since 1947.
The network continued its hot streak into the early 1990s with new hits such as The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air, Blossom, and Law & Order.
NBC's "Must See TV" started in 1991.
Brandon Tartikoff left his role as NBC's President of Entertainment in 1991 to take an executive position at Paramount Pictures.
Warren Littlefield succeeded Tartikoff as entertainment president in 1991.
Most of the Tartikoff-era hits ended their runs
Friends is a television show that ended its final season as the leader in the Nielsen ratings for a single television season.
Only two other shows, I Love Lucy and The Andy Griffith Show, had finished their runs at the top of the ratings before Friends.
Friends emerged as NBC's biggest television show after the 1998 Seinfeld final broadcast.
Friends dominated the ratings, never leaving the top five watched shows of the year from its second through tenth seasons.
Friends landed on the number-one spot during season eight in the 2001-02 season as the latest sitcom in the U.S. to lead the annual Nielsen primetime television ratings.
Frasier is a Cheers spinoff that became a critical and commercial success.
Frasier usually landed in the Nielsen Top 20.
The ratings of Frasier were overshadowed to a minor extent by Friends.
Frasier went on to win numerous Emmy Awards.
In 1994, NBC began branding its strong Thursday night lineup under the "Must See TV" tagline.
The "Must See TV" tagline was also applied to NBC's comedy blocks on other nights, particularly on Tuesdays.
Between September 1994 and September 1996, NBC affiliated with several stations that were affected by the 1994-96 United States broadcast TV realignment.
WBAL-TV, WHDH (Boston), and WCAU (Philadelphia) were involved in an affiliation deal between Westinghouse Broadcasting and CBS.
KSHB-TV (Kansas City) was involved in an affiliation deal between New World Communications and Fox.
WCBD-TV (Charleston) was involved in an affiliation deal between Allbritton Communications and ABC.
WGBA-TV (Green Bay), WPMI-TV (Mobile) and KHNL (Honolulu) were part of an agreement between Fox and SF Broadcasting.
By the mid-1990s, NBC's sports division had rights to three of the four major professional sports leagues
NBC's longstanding ratings lead ended in the year when CBS overtook it for first place.
In 2001, CBS moved its hit reality series Survivor to serve as the anchor of its Thursday night lineup.
The success of Survivor suggested that NBC's nearly two decades of dominance on Thursday nights could be broken.
Friends, Will & Grace, ER and Just Shoot Me! helped NBC continue to lead the Thursday ratings in the 2000-01 season.
Just Shoot Me! saw its highest viewership following its move to Thursday nights in the 2000-01 season.
Between the 2001-02 and 2004-05 seasons, NBC became the first major network to air select dramas in letterbox over its analog broadcast feed.
The move to air dramas in letterbox was done in the hopes of attracting new viewers.
NBC saw only a slight boost in viewership after airing dramas in letterbox.
NBC retook its first-place lead in the ratings in the year after airing select dramas in letterbox.
NBC spent much of the next four years in the top spot in the ratings.
NBC lost the broadcast rights to Major League Baseball to Fox after the 2000 season.
NBC only had alternating rights to the All-Star Game, League Championship Series and World Series before losing the broadcast rights to Major League Baseball.
NBC lost the broadcast rights to the NBA to ABC after the 2001-02 season.
NBC's major sports offerings were reduced to the Olympics, PGA Tour golf events and a floundering Notre Dame football program after losing the broadcast rights to the NBA.
NBC acquired Spanish-language network Telemundo from Liberty Media and Sony Pictures Entertainment for $2.7 billion in October 2001.
NBC beat out other bidders including CBS/Viacom for the acquisition of Telemundo.
The deal to acquire Telemundo was finalized in 2002.
Vivendi Universal sold 80% of its film and television subsidi
During the 2006-07 season, NBC's ratings fell to fourth place, behind ABC, Fox, and CBS.
At that time, all networks faced audience erosion from increased competition by cable television, home video, video games, and the Internet.
NBC was the hardest hit among the networks.
The 2006-07 season was a mixed bag for NBC.
The show "Deal or No Deal" remained strong.
The show "Heroes" became a surprise hit on Monday nights.
The show "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip" lost a third of its premiere-night viewers by Week 6 and was eventually canceled.
The critically acclaimed sitcoms "The Office" and "30 Rock" pulled in modest successes.
These two shows went on to win the Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series for four consecutive years.
NBC regained the rights to the NFL after eight years that season when it acquired the Sunday Night Football package from ESPN.
Despite acquiring the NFL rights, NBC remained at a very distant fourth place, barely ranking ahead of The CW.
NBC experienced success with its summer schedule, despite its declining ratings during the main broadcast season.
The reality talent competition series "America's Got Talent" premiered in 2006 and earned a 4.6 rating in the 18-49 demographic.
The show's ratings were higher than that earned by the 2002 premiere of Fox's American Idol.
Despite the high ratings, NBC decided not to place "America's Got Talent" in the spring season.
Instead, NBC used the show as a platform to promote their upcoming fall shows.
In 2007, Kevin Reilly was unexpectedly terminated and Ben Silverman was appointed president of NBC Entertainment.
Jeff Zucker was promoted to succeed Bob Wright as CEO of NBC.
NBC failed to generate any new primetime hits during the 2008-09 season.
The sitcom "Parks and Recreation" survived for a second
The 2009-2010 television season for NBC ended with only two scripted shows being renewed for second seasons.
Community and Parenthood were the two scripted shows renewed by NBC for second seasons.
The Marriage Ref, Who Do You Think You Are? and Minute to Win It were the three unscripted shows renewed by NBC for second seasons.
Heroes and Law & Order were cancelled by NBC.
Law & Order ended after 20 seasons, tying it with Gunsmoke as the longest-running prime time drama in U.S. television history.
Conan O'Brien succeeded Jay Leno as host of The Tonight Show in 2009.
NBC gave Leno a new prime time talk show, The Jay Leno Show, which aired every weeknight at 10:00 p.m. Eastern and Pacific.
The Jay Leno Show was an inexpensive comedic alternative to the police procedurals and other hour-long dramas typically aired in that time slot.
NBC was the first major U.S. broadcast network in decades to broadcast the same program in a week daily prime time strip.
NBC executives called the decision to air The Jay Leno Show in prime time a transformational moment in the history of broadcasting.
Industry executives criticized NBC for abandoning a history of airing quality dramas in the 10:00 hour.
Complaints from many affiliates saw their late-evening newscasts drop significantly in the local ratings during The Jay Leno Show's run.
NBC announced on January 10, 2010, that it would drop Leno's show from the 10:00 p.m. slot.
Zucker announced plans to shift The Jay Leno Show into the 11:35 p.m. slot and shift its existing late night lineup by 30 minutes.
The removal of The Jay Leno Show from its prime time schedule had almost no impact on the network's ratings.
The shows that occupied the 10:00 p.m. time slot drew lower numbers than The Jay Leno
Super Bowl XLVI was the most-watched program in U.S. television history at the time, and it was broadcast on NBC.
The network's Monday night midseason lineup of The Voice and musical-drama Smash was very successful.
NBC managed to lift itself into third place in the 18–49 demographic in the 2011–12 season.
The success of SNF, The Voice, and Smash helped NBC break its eight-year streak in fourth place.
Four shows survived for a second season on NBC in the 2012–13 season.
Three of the shows that survived for a second season were cancelled in the following year.
None of the shows that survived for a second season were unqualified ratings successes.
NBC remained a distant fourth place in total viewership in the 2012–13 season.
In the fall of 2012, NBC greatly expanded its sitcom roster, with eight comedy series airing on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights.
NBC bounced back to first place network in adults 18–49 that fall.
The new season of The Voice, the initial success of freshman drama Revolution and sitcom Go On, and the continued strength of Sunday Night Football helped NBC boost its ratings.
Withholding the new season of The Voice and benching Revolution until late March caused the network's midseason ratings to suffer.
NBC's midseason ratings fell to fifth place behind Spanish-language network Univision during the February sweeps period.
The 2012–13 season ended with NBC finishing in third place overall.
Only three new shows, all dramas, survived for a second season on NBC in the 2012–13 season.
NBC Sports migrated its business and production operations (including NBCSN) to new facilities in Stamford, Connecticut in 2013.
Production of the network's NFL pre-game show Football Night in America remained at the NBC Studios at Rockefeller Center.
Production operations of Football Night in America were based in Studio 8G.
The
NBC aired a new workplace sitcom called Superstore in November 2015, after The Voice.
The official launch of Superstore was in January 2016.
Superstore received decent ratings for a new comedy without The Voice as a lead-in.
Superstore was renewed for a second season in February 2016.
The comedy-drama This Is Us premiered on NBC during the 2016-2017 season.
Critics received This Is Us well.
This Is Us brought high ratings.
NBC renewed This Is Us for two additional seasons in January 2017.
The Blacklist brought modest ratings for NBC during the 2016-2017 season.
The Blacklist: Redemption, a spinoff of The Blacklist, failed to launch.
NBC added a third spinoff to the Chicago franchise, Chicago Justice, during the 2016-2017 season.
Workplace sitcom Superstore continued its success in its second season.
The Good Place, a fantasy sitcom, premiered on NBC following The Voice during the 2016-2017 season.
The Good Place brought in modest ratings.
NBC renewed The Good Place for a second season in January 2017.
The Wall premiered during the summer time period prior to the 2017-2018 season, with modest ratings.
Ellen's Game of Games premiered on NBC during the 2017-2018 season.
Will & Grace returned to NBC during the 2017-2018 season, after its final episode in 2006.
The Titan Games, Manifest, Songland, and New Amsterdam premiered on NBC during the 2018-2019 season.
The Titan Games, Manifest, Songland, and New Amsterdam were renewed for additional seasons.
The Village and The Enemy Within did not make it past their first seasons on NBC.
NBC was the top-rated network
